questions.text: The physical examination of a patient shows the presence of scleral icterus but doesn’t show yellowish discolouration of the skin. The finding indicates a serum bilirubin level of at least?
questions.correct_answer: C. 51 μmol/L
questions.explanation:
Solution:

51 μmol/L Sclerae have a particular affinity for bilirubin due to their high elastin content, and the presence of scleral icterus indicates a serum bilirubin level of at least 51 μmol/L (3 mg/dL).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Normal level. With the van den Bergh method , the normal serum bilirubin concentration usually is between 17 and 26 μmol/L (1 and 1.5 mg/dL). Total serum bilirubin concentrations are between 3.4 and 15.4 μmol/L (0.2 and 0.9 mg/dL) in 95% of the average population. Option: B: Jaundice is rarely detectable with a bilirubin level <43 μmol/L (2.5 mg/dL).

questions.text: Which of the following causes Carotenoderma?

Solution:

Excessive consumption of leafy vegetables Carotenoderma is the yellow color imparted to the skin of healthy individuals who ingest excessive amounts of vegetables and fruits that contain carotenes, such as carrots, leafy vegetables, squash, peaches, and oranges.

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a complaint of tea- or cola-colored urine. Biochemical investigation shows increased serum bilirubin. Renal excretion of which of the following causes darkening of the urine?
questions.correct_answer: D. Conjugated bilirubin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conjugated bilirubin A sensitive indicator of increased serum bilirubin is the darkening of the urine due to the renal excretion of conjugated bilirubin . Patients often describe their urine as tea- or cola-colored . Bilirubinuria indicates an elevation of the direct serum bilirubin fraction and, therefore, the presence of liver or biliary disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B: Bilirubin is excreted here. Option: C: Unconjugated bilirubin is always bound to albumin in the serum , is not filtered by the kidney, and is not found in the urine. Any bilirubin found in the urine is conjugated bilirubin.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with c/o yellowish discolouration of the skin and mucous membrane. His sclerae are yellow on examination. Which of the following is/are a source of yellowish discolouration?

options.label: A
options.text: Prematurely destroyed erythroid cells in bone marrow

options.label: B
options.text: The turnover of hemoproteins such as myoglobin and cytochromes

options.label: C
options.text: Breakdown of hemoglobin in senescent red blood cells

questions.correct_answer: D. All of the above
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above About 80–85% of the 4 mg/kg body weight of bilirubin produced daily is derived from the breakdown of hemoglobin in senescent red blood cells. The remainder comes from prematurely destroyed erythroid cells in the bone marrow and the turnover of hemoproteins such as myoglobin and cytochromes found in tissues throughout the body.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B: About 10–15% comes from prematurely destroyed erythroid cells in the bone marrow and the turnover of hemoproteins such as myoglobin and cytochromes found in tissues throughout the body. Option: C: About 80–85% of the daily 4 mg/kg body weight of bilirubin is derived.

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about Delta bilirubin?

options.label: B
options.text: A false-positive result on urine dipstick test

options.label: D
options.text: Not filtered by the renal glomeruli

questions.correct_answer: B. A false-positive result on urine dipstick test
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A false-positive result on urine dipstick test A false-negative result is possible in patients with prolonged cholestasis due to the predominance of delta bilirubin, which is covalently bound to albumin and, therefore, not filtered by the renal glomeruli nor in bile. This albumin-linked fraction of conjugated bilirubin ( delta fraction, delta bilirubin, or biliprotein) represents an essential fraction of total serum bilirubin in patients with cholestasis and hepatobiliary disorders . The Delta bilirubin is formed in serum when hepatic excretion of bilirubin glucuronides is impaired, and the glucuronides accumulate in serum. By its tight binding to albumin, the clearance rate of delta bilirubin from serum approximates the half-life of albumin ( 12–14 days ) rather than the short half-life of bilirubin (about 4 h). The prolonged half-life of albumin-bound conjugated bilirubin accounts for two previously unexplained enigmas in jaundiced patients with liver disease: (1) that some patients with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia do not exhibit bilirubinuria during the recovery phase of their disease because the delta bilirubin, although conjugated, is covalently bound to albumin and therefore not filtered by the renal glomeruli and (2) The elevated serum bilirubin level declines more slowly than expected in some patients who otherwise appear to recover satisfactorily.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, C: As conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is always associated with bilirubinuria (except in the presence of delta bilirubin in prolonged cholestasis when jaundice is overt) Option: D: Covalently bound to albumin and therefore not filtered by the renal glomeruli.

questions.text: The LFT report of a patient shows Hyperbilirubinemia with a total bilirubin of 10 mg%, of which indirect is 7 mg%. Which of the following is an inherited cause of this clinical picture?
questions.correct_answer: B. Dubin-Johnson syndrome
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dubin-Johnson syndrome Elevated conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is found in two rare inherited conditions: Dubin-Johnson and Rotor syndrome . (code Direct —DR)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Patients with Gilbert’s syndrome have mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with serum levels almost always < 103 μmol/L (6 mg/dL).\ Option: C: Impaired bilirubin conjugation in patients with Crigler-Najjar type II live into adulthood with serum bilirubin levels of 103–428 μmol/L (6–25 mg/dL)

questions.text: The LFT of a 28-year male shows purely unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. What maximum value of sustained hyperbilirubinemia can be present in hemolytic disorder with normal hepatic function?
questions.correct_answer: D. 20 mg/dL
questions.explanation:
Solution:

20 mg/dL The bone marrow can only sustain an eightfold increase in erythrocyte production in response to hemolytic stress. Hemolysis alone cannot result in a sustained hyperbilirubinemia of more than ~68 μmol/L (4 mg/dL) . Higher values imply concomitant hepatic dysfunction. When hemolysis is the only abnormality in an otherwise healthy individual, the result is a purely unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with the direct-reacting fraction ≤ 15% of the total serum bilirubin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B, C, D: Cannot be seen without concomitant hepatic dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is mainly responsible for the clearance and elimination of bilirubin produced in the fetus?

options.label: A
options.text: Cleared by the fetal liver and eliminated by fetal kidney

options.label: B
options.text: Cleared by the fetal liver and eliminated in the GI tract of fetus

options.label: C
options.text: Cleared by the fetal liver and eliminated by the maternal liver

options.label: D
options.text: Cleared by the placenta and eliminated by the maternal liver

questions.correct_answer: D. Cleared by the placenta and eliminated by the maternal liver
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cleared by the placenta and eliminated by the maternal liver Bilirubin produced by the fetus is cleared by the placenta and eliminated by the maternal liver. Immediately after birth, the neonatal liver must assume bilirubin clearance and excretion responsibility .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B, C: Fetal liver is not mature to conjugate the bilirubin .

questions.text: All are true about Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Most patients have no symptoms at the time of diagnosis

options.label: C
options.text: 50–75% of patients with PSC have IBD

options.label: D
options.text: ~5% of patients with UC have PSC

questions.correct_answer: A. PSC is commonly pANCA negative
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PSC is commonly pANCA negative PSC can be detected earlier or even years after proctocolectomy. The immunogenetic basis for PSC appears to be overlapping but distinct from UC based on GWAS, although both IBD and PSC are commonly pANCA positive.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B: Most patients have no symptoms at the time of diagnosis; when symptoms are present, they consist of fatigue, jaundice, abdominal pain, fever, anorexia, and malaise. Option: C, D: ~5% of patients with UC have PSC, but 50–75% of patients with PSC have IBD. PSC occurs less often in patients with CD.

Extraedge:

Around 65%of PSC patients are pANCA positive. All patients diagnosed with sclerosing cholangitis should have a serum IgG4 level checked to rule out IgG4 disease as a cause of secondary sclerosing cholangitis, particularly if they do not have inflammatory bowel disease

questions.text: A patient with Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is diagnosed with a gallbladder polyp measuring about 1 cm in diameter. What is the recommended treatment?
questions.correct_answer: D. Cholecystectomy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholecystectomy Gallbladder polyps in patients with PSC have a high incidence of malignancy, and cholecystectomy is recommended, even if a mass lesion is less than 1 cm in diameter. Gallbladder surveillance with ultrasound should be performed annually.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, C: Needs surgical intervention. Option: B: Follow-up is done if no lesion is seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no specific proven treatment for PSC

options.label: C
options.text: Development of cholangiocarcinoma is an indication of liver transplantation

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic dilatation of dominant strictures can be helpful

questions.correct_answer: C. Development of cholangiocarcinoma is an indication of liver transplantation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Development of cholangiocarcinoma is an indication of liver transplantation A dreaded complication of PSC is the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a relative contraindication to liver transplantation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: There is no specific proven treatment for PSC. A recently completed study of high-dose (20 mg/kg per day) UDCA was found to be harmful. Some clinicians use UDCA at ‘PBC dosages’ of 13–15 mg/kg daily with anecdotal improvement. Option: B, D: Endoscopic dilatation of dominant strictures can be helpful, but the ultimate treatment is liver transplantation.

questions.text: What is the earliest lesion in Primary biliary cholangitis?

options.label: B
options.text: The number of bile ducts is reduced

options.label: C
options.text: Expansion of periportal fibrosis to bridging fibrosis

questions.correct_answer: D. Chronic nonsuppurative destructive cholangitis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic nonsuppurative destructive cholangitis The earliest lesion is termed chronic nonsuppurative destructive cholangitis and is a necrotising inflammatory process of the portal tracts. Medium and small bile ducts are infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo duct destruction. Mild fibrosis and sometimes bile stasis can occur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B, C: With progression, the number of bile ducts is reduced, and there is the proliferation of smaller bile ductules . Increased fibrosis ensues with the expansion of periportal fibrosis to bridging fibrosis. Finally, cirrhosis develops, which can be micro or Macronodular

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about the treatment of Primary biliary cholangitis?

Bisphosphonate is contraindicated Treatment with a bisphosphonate should be instituted when bone disease is identified.

Option: B: Pruritus is treated with antihistamines, narcotic receptor antagonists (naltrexone), and rifampin. Option: D: Cholestyramine, a bile salt–sequestering agent , has been helpful in some patients but is somewhat tedious and difficult to take.

questions.correct_answer: A. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: intrahepatic bile duct beading, Stricturing and dilatation, and extrahepatic bile duct are also diffusely strictured
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis: intrahepatic bile duct beading, Stricturing and dilatation, and extrahepatic bile duct are also diffusely strictured Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatogram Is the first investigation Of choice. There is intrahepatic bile duct beading, Stricturing and dilatation . The extrahepatic bile duct is also diffusely strictured. Clinical presentation is also typical of PSC.

Extraedge:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is strongly associated with Ulcerative colitis. 90% Of PSC patients have Ulcerative colitis, but only 5% of patients with Ulcerative colitis have PSC. Pancolitis and Rectal sparing type of ULcerative colitis is seen in PSC.

questions.text: A 30-year male shows the following histological finding on liver biopsy. Identify the finding and probable diagnosis:
questions.correct_answer: C. Onion skin scarring: Early PSC
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Onion skin scarring: Early PSC On liver biopsy, the characteristic early features of PSC are periductal ‘onion skin’ fibrosis and inflammation, with portal oedema and bile ductular proliferation resulting in expansion of the portal tracts.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Later, fibrosis spreads, progressing inevitably to biliary cirrhosis; obliterative cholangitis leads to the so-called ‘ vanishing bile duct syndrome’. Option: B, D: Onion skin scarring is seen, NOT hemorrhage.
